trans-unit.source: Apache Storm topologies with Visual Studio and C# | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm topologies with Visual Studio and C# | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create Storm topologies in C# by creating a simple word count topology in Visual Studio using the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create Storm topologies in C# by creating a simple word count topology in Visual Studio using the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Develop C# topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight using Hadoop tools for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Develop C# topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight using Hadoop tools for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a C# Storm topology by using the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a C# Storm topology by using the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks through the process of creating a new Storm project in Visual Studio, testing it locally, and deploying it to an Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks through the process of creating a new Storm project in Visual Studio, testing it locally, and deploying it to an Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: You will also learn how to create hybrid topologies that use C# and Java components.
trans-unit.target: You will also learn how to create hybrid topologies that use C# and Java components.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: One of the following versions of Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: One of the following versions of Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2012 with <link><linkText>Update 4</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2012 with <link><linkText>Update 4</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 with <link><linkText>Update 4</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Community</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 with <link><linkText>Update 4</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Community</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015 or <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2015 Community</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015 or <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2015 Community</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Azure SDK 2.5.1 or later
trans-unit.target: Azure SDK 2.5.1 or later

trans-unit.source: HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio: See <link><linkText>Get started using HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> to install and configure the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio: See <link><linkText>Get started using HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> to install and configure the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio are not supported on Visual Studio Express
trans-unit.target: HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio are not supported on Visual Studio Express

trans-unit.source: Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster: See <link><linkText>Getting started with Apache Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link> for steps to create a cluster.
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster: See <link><linkText>Getting started with Apache Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link> for steps to create a cluster.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio only support Storm on HDInsight versions 3.2 clusters.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio only support Storm on HDInsight versions 3.2 clusters.

trans-unit.source: A basic word count topology
trans-unit.target: A basic word count topology

trans-unit.source: The HBase reader and writer samples use the HBase REST API to communicate with an HBase on HDInsight cluster, not the HBase Java API.
trans-unit.target: The HBase reader and writer samples use the HBase REST API to communicate with an HBase on HDInsight cluster, not the HBase Java API.

trans-unit.source: In the steps in this document, you will use the basic Storm Application project type to create a new topology.
trans-unit.target: In the steps in this document, you will use the basic Storm Application project type to create a new topology.

trans-unit.source: Create a C# topology
trans-unit.target: Create a C# topology

trans-unit.source: If you have not already installed the latest version of the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Get started using HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you have not already installed the latest version of the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Get started using HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio, select File > New, and then Project.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio, select File > New, and then Project.

trans-unit.source: From the New Project screen, expand Installed > Templates, and select HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: From the New Project screen, expand Installed > Templates, and select HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: From the list of templates, select Storm Application.
trans-unit.target: From the list of templates, select Storm Application.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the screen, enter WordCount as the name of the application.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the screen, enter WordCount as the name of the application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After the project has been created, you should have the following files:
trans-unit.target: After the project has been created, you should have the following files:

trans-unit.source: Program.cs: This defines the topology for your project.
trans-unit.target: Program.cs: This defines the topology for your project.

trans-unit.source: Note that a default topology that consists of one spout and one bolt is created by default.
trans-unit.target: Note that a default topology that consists of one spout and one bolt is created by default.

trans-unit.source: Spout.cs: An example spout that emits random numbers.
trans-unit.target: Spout.cs: An example spout that emits random numbers.

trans-unit.source: Bolt.cs: An example bolt that keeps a count of numbers emitted by the spout.
trans-unit.target: Bolt.cs: An example bolt that keeps a count of numbers emitted by the spout.

trans-unit.source: As part of project creation, the latest <link><linkText>SCP.NET packages</linkText><title></title></link> will be downloaded from NuGet.
trans-unit.target: As part of project creation, the latest <link><linkText>SCP.NET packages</linkText><title></title></link> will be downloaded from NuGet.

trans-unit.source: In the next sections, you will modify this project into a basic WordCount application.
trans-unit.target: In the next sections, you will modify this project into a basic WordCount application.

trans-unit.source: Implement the spout
trans-unit.target: Implement the spout

trans-unit.source: Open Spout.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open Spout.cs.

trans-unit.source: Spouts are used to read data in a topology from an external source.
trans-unit.target: Spouts are used to read data in a topology from an external source.

trans-unit.source: The main components for a spout are:
trans-unit.target: The main components for a spout are:

trans-unit.source: NextTuple: Called by Storm when the spout is allowed to emit new tuples.
trans-unit.target: NextTuple: Called by Storm when the spout is allowed to emit new tuples.

trans-unit.source: Ack (transactional topology only): Handles acknowledgements initiated by other components in the topology for tuples sent from this spout.
trans-unit.target: Ack (transactional topology only): Handles acknowledgements initiated by other components in the topology for tuples sent from this spout.

trans-unit.source: Acknowledging a tuple lets the spout know that it was processed successfully by downstream components.
trans-unit.target: Acknowledging a tuple lets the spout know that it was processed successfully by downstream components.

trans-unit.source: Fail (transactional topology only): Handles tuples that are fail-processing other components in the topology.
trans-unit.target: Fail (transactional topology only): Handles tuples that are fail-processing other components in the topology.

trans-unit.source: This provides the opportunity to re-emit the tuple so that it can be processed again.
trans-unit.target: This provides the opportunity to re-emit the tuple so that it can be processed again.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the Spout class with the following.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the Spout class with the following.

trans-unit.source: This creates a spout that randomly emits a sentence into the topology.
trans-unit.target: This creates a spout that randomly emits a sentence into the topology.

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.

trans-unit.source: Implement the bolts
trans-unit.target: Implement the bolts

trans-unit.source: Delete the existing Bolt.cs file from the project.
trans-unit.target: Delete the existing Bolt.cs file from the project.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Add > New item.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Add > New item.

trans-unit.source: From the list, select Storm Bolt, and enter Splitter.cs as the name.
trans-unit.target: From the list, select Storm Bolt, and enter Splitter.cs as the name.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this to create a second bolt named Counter.cs.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this to create a second bolt named Counter.cs.

trans-unit.source: Splitter.cs: Implements a bolt that splits sentences into individual words and emits a new stream of words.
trans-unit.target: Splitter.cs: Implements a bolt that splits sentences into individual words and emits a new stream of words.

trans-unit.source: Counter.cs: Implements a bolt that counts each word and emits a new stream of words and the count for each word.
trans-unit.target: Counter.cs: Implements a bolt that counts each word and emits a new stream of words and the count for each word.

trans-unit.source: These bolts simply read and write to streams, but you can also use a bolt to communicate with sources such as a database or service.
trans-unit.target: These bolts simply read and write to streams, but you can also use a bolt to communicate with sources such as a database or service.

trans-unit.source: Open Splitter.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open Splitter.cs.

trans-unit.source: Note that it has only one method by default: Execute.
trans-unit.target: Note that it has only one method by default: Execute.

trans-unit.source: This is called when the bolt receives a tuple for processing.
trans-unit.target: This is called when the bolt receives a tuple for processing.

trans-unit.source: Here, you can read and process incoming tuples, and emit outbound tuples.
trans-unit.target: Here, you can read and process incoming tuples, and emit outbound tuples.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the Splitter class with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the Splitter class with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.

trans-unit.source: Open Counter.cs and replace the class contents with the following:
trans-unit.target: Open Counter.cs and replace the class contents with the following:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.

trans-unit.source: Define the topology
trans-unit.target: Define the topology

trans-unit.source: Spouts and bolts are arranged in a graph, which defines how the data flows between components.
trans-unit.target: Spouts and bolts are arranged in a graph, which defines how the data flows between components.

trans-unit.source: For this topology, the graph is as follows:
trans-unit.target: For this topology, the graph is as follows:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image of how components are arranged</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image of how components are arranged</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Sentences are emitted from the spout, which are distributed to instances of the Splitter bolt.
trans-unit.target: Sentences are emitted from the spout, which are distributed to instances of the Splitter bolt.

trans-unit.source: The Splitter bolt breaks the sentences into words, which are distributed to the Counter bolt.
trans-unit.target: The Splitter bolt breaks the sentences into words, which are distributed to the Counter bolt.

trans-unit.source: Because word count is held locally in the Counter instance, we want to make sure that specific words flow to the same Counter bolt instance, so we have only one instance keeping track of a specific word.
trans-unit.target: Because word count is held locally in the Counter instance, we want to make sure that specific words flow to the same Counter bolt instance, so we have only one instance keeping track of a specific word.

trans-unit.source: But for the Splitter bolt, it really doesn't matter which bolt receives which sentence, so we simply want to load balance sentences across those instances.
trans-unit.target: But for the Splitter bolt, it really doesn't matter which bolt receives which sentence, so we simply want to load balance sentences across those instances.

trans-unit.source: Open Program.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open Program.cs.

trans-unit.source: The important method is ITopologyBuilder, which is used to define the topology that is submitted to Storm.
trans-unit.target: The important method is ITopologyBuilder, which is used to define the topology that is submitted to Storm.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of ITopologyBuilder with the following code to implement the topology described previously:
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of ITopologyBuilder with the following code to implement the topology described previously:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the comments to understand what this code does.

trans-unit.source: Submit the topology
trans-unit.target: Submit the topology

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: If prompted, enter the login credentials for your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If prompted, enter the login credentials for your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, log in to the one that contains your Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, log in to the one that contains your Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Select your Storm on HDInsight cluster from the Storm Cluster drop-down list, and then select Submit.
trans-unit.target: Select your Storm on HDInsight cluster from the Storm Cluster drop-down list, and then select Submit.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor if the submission is successful by using the Output window.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor if the submission is successful by using the Output window.

trans-unit.source: When the topology has been successfully submitted, the Storm Topologies for the cluster should appear.
trans-unit.target: When the topology has been successfully submitted, the Storm Topologies for the cluster should appear.

trans-unit.source: Select the WordCount topology from the list to view information about the running topology.
trans-unit.target: Select the WordCount topology from the list to view information about the running topology.

trans-unit.source: You can also view Storm Topologies from Server Explorer: Expand Azure > HDInsight, right-click a Storm on HDInsight cluster, and then select View Storm Topologies.
trans-unit.target: You can also view Storm Topologies from Server Explorer: Expand Azure > HDInsight, right-click a Storm on HDInsight cluster, and then select View Storm Topologies.

trans-unit.source: Use the links for the spouts or bolts to view information about these components.
trans-unit.target: Use the links for the spouts or bolts to view information about these components.

trans-unit.source: A new window will be opened for each item selected.
trans-unit.target: A new window will be opened for each item selected.

trans-unit.source: From the Topology Summary view, click Kill to stop the topology.
trans-unit.target: From the Topology Summary view, click Kill to stop the topology.

trans-unit.source: Storm topologies continue to run until they are deactivated, or the cluster is deleted.
trans-unit.target: Storm topologies continue to run until they are deactivated, or the cluster is deleted.

trans-unit.source: Transactional topology
trans-unit.target: Transactional topology

trans-unit.source: The previous topology is non-transactional.
trans-unit.target: The previous topology is non-transactional.

trans-unit.source: The components within the topology do not implement any functionality for replaying messages if processing fails by a component in the topology.
trans-unit.target: The components within the topology do not implement any functionality for replaying messages if processing fails by a component in the topology.

trans-unit.source: For an example transactional topology, create a new project and select Storm Sample as the project type.
trans-unit.target: For an example transactional topology, create a new project and select Storm Sample as the project type.

trans-unit.source: Transactional topologies implement the following to support replay of data:
trans-unit.target: Transactional topologies implement the following to support replay of data:

trans-unit.source: Metadata caching: The spout must store metadata about the data emitted so that the data can be retrieved and emitted again if a failure occurs.
trans-unit.target: Metadata caching: The spout must store metadata about the data emitted so that the data can be retrieved and emitted again if a failure occurs.

trans-unit.source: Because the data emitted by the sample is small, the raw data for each tuple is stored in a dictionary for replay.
trans-unit.target: Because the data emitted by the sample is small, the raw data for each tuple is stored in a dictionary for replay.

trans-unit.source: Ack: Each bolt in the topology can call this.ctx.Ack(tuple) to ack that it has successfully processed a tuple.
trans-unit.target: Ack: Each bolt in the topology can call this.ctx.Ack(tuple) to ack that it has successfully processed a tuple.

trans-unit.source: When all bolts have acked the tuple, the Ack method of the spout is invoked.
trans-unit.target: When all bolts have acked the tuple, the Ack method of the spout is invoked.

trans-unit.source: This allows the spout to remove cached data for replay because the data was completely processed.
trans-unit.target: This allows the spout to remove cached data for replay because the data was completely processed.

trans-unit.source: Fail: Each bolt can call this.ctx.Fail(tuple) to indicate that processing has failed for a tuple.
trans-unit.target: Fail: Each bolt can call this.ctx.Fail(tuple) to indicate that processing has failed for a tuple.

trans-unit.source: The failure propagates to the Fail method of the spout, where the tuple can be replayed by using cached metadata.
trans-unit.target: The failure propagates to the Fail method of the spout, where the tuple can be replayed by using cached metadata.

trans-unit.source: Sequence ID: When emitting a tuple, a sequence ID can be specified.
trans-unit.target: Sequence ID: When emitting a tuple, a sequence ID can be specified.

trans-unit.source: This should be a value that identifies the tuple for replay (Ack and Fail) processing.
trans-unit.target: This should be a value that identifies the tuple for replay (Ack and Fail) processing.

trans-unit.source: For example, the spout in the Storm Sample project uses the following when emitting data:
trans-unit.target: For example, the spout in the Storm Sample project uses the following when emitting data:

trans-unit.source: This emits a new tuple that contains a sentence to the default stream, with the sequence ID value contained in lastSeqId.
trans-unit.target: This emits a new tuple that contains a sentence to the default stream, with the sequence ID value contained in lastSeqId.

trans-unit.source: For this example, lastSeqId is simply incremented for every tuple emitted.
trans-unit.target: For this example, lastSeqId is simply incremented for every tuple emitted.

trans-unit.source: As demonstrated in the Storm Sample project, whether a component is transactional can be set at run time, based on configuration.
trans-unit.target: As demonstrated in the Storm Sample project, whether a component is transactional can be set at run time, based on configuration.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid topology
trans-unit.target: Hybrid topology

trans-unit.source: HDInsight tools for Visual Studio can also be used to create hybrid topologies, where some components are C# and others are Java.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight tools for Visual Studio can also be used to create hybrid topologies, where some components are C# and others are Java.

trans-unit.source: For an example hybrid topology, create a new project, and select Storm Hybrid Sample.
trans-unit.target: For an example hybrid topology, create a new project, and select Storm Hybrid Sample.

trans-unit.source: This creates a fully commented sample that contains several topologies that demonstrate the following:
trans-unit.target: This creates a fully commented sample that contains several topologies that demonstrate the following:

trans-unit.source: Java spout and C# bolt: Defined in HybridTopology_javaSpout_csharpBolt
trans-unit.target: Java spout and C# bolt: Defined in HybridTopology_javaSpout_csharpBolt

trans-unit.source: A transactional version is defined in HybridTopologyTx_javaSpout_csharpBolt
trans-unit.target: A transactional version is defined in HybridTopologyTx_javaSpout_csharpBolt

trans-unit.source: C# spout and Java bolt: Defined in HybridTopology_csharpSpout_javaBolt
trans-unit.target: C# spout and Java bolt: Defined in HybridTopology_csharpSpout_javaBolt

trans-unit.source: A transactional version is defined in HybridTopologyTx_csharpSpout_javaBolt
trans-unit.target: A transactional version is defined in HybridTopologyTx_csharpSpout_javaBolt

trans-unit.source: This version also demonstrates how to use Clojure code from a text file as a Java component.
trans-unit.target: This version also demonstrates how to use Clojure code from a text file as a Java component.

trans-unit.source: To switch between the topology that is used when the project is submitted, simply move the [Active(true)] statement to the topology you want to use before submitting it to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: To switch between the topology that is used when the project is submitted, simply move the [Active(true)] statement to the topology you want to use before submitting it to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: All the Java files that are required are provided as part of this project in the JavaDependency folder.
trans-unit.target: All the Java files that are required are provided as part of this project in the JavaDependency folder.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following when creating and submitting a hybrid topology:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following when creating and submitting a hybrid topology:

trans-unit.source: JavaComponentConstructor must be used to create a new instance of the Java class for a spout or bolt.
trans-unit.target: JavaComponentConstructor must be used to create a new instance of the Java class for a spout or bolt.

trans-unit.source: microsoft.scp.storm.multilang.CustomizedInteropJSONSerializer should be used to serialize data in to or out of Java components from Java objects to JSON.
trans-unit.target: microsoft.scp.storm.multilang.CustomizedInteropJSONSerializer should be used to serialize data in to or out of Java components from Java objects to JSON.

trans-unit.source: When submitting the topology to the server, you must use the Additional configurations option to specify the Java File paths.
trans-unit.target: When submitting the topology to the server, you must use the Additional configurations option to specify the Java File paths.

trans-unit.source: The path specified should be the directory that contains the JAR files that contain your Java classes.
trans-unit.target: The path specified should be the directory that contains the JAR files that contain your Java classes.

trans-unit.source: Azure Event Hubs
trans-unit.target: Azure Event Hubs

trans-unit.source: SCP.Net version 0.9.4.203 introduces a new class and method specifically for working with the Event Hub Spout (a Java spout that reads from Event Hub.)
trans-unit.target: SCP.Net version 0.9.4.203 introduces a new class and method specifically for working with the Event Hub Spout (a Java spout that reads from Event Hub.)

trans-unit.source: When creating a topology that uses this spout, use the following methods:
trans-unit.target: When creating a topology that uses this spout, use the following methods:

trans-unit.source: EventHubSpoutConfig class: creates an object that contains the configuration for the spout component
trans-unit.target: EventHubSpoutConfig class: creates an object that contains the configuration for the spout component

trans-unit.source: TopologyBuilder.SetEventHubSpout method: adds the Event Hub Spout component to the topology
trans-unit.target: TopologyBuilder.SetEventHubSpout method: adds the Event Hub Spout component to the topology

trans-unit.source: While these make it easier to work with the Event Hub Spout than other Java components, you must still use the CustomizedInteropJSONSerializer to serialize data produced by the spout.
trans-unit.target: While these make it easier to work with the Event Hub Spout than other Java components, you must still use the CustomizedInteropJSONSerializer to serialize data produced by the spout.

trans-unit.source: How to update SCP.NET
trans-unit.target: How to update SCP.NET

trans-unit.source: Recent releases of SCP.NET support package upgrade through NuGet.
trans-unit.target: Recent releases of SCP.NET support package upgrade through NuGet.

trans-unit.source: When a new update is available, you will receive an upgrade notification.
trans-unit.target: When a new update is available, you will receive an upgrade notification.

trans-unit.source: To manually check for an upgrade, perform these steps:
trans-unit.target: To manually check for an upgrade, perform these steps:

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: From the package manager, select Updates.
trans-unit.target: From the package manager, select Updates.

trans-unit.source: If an update is available, it will be listed.
trans-unit.target: If an update is available, it will be listed.

trans-unit.source: Click the Update button for the package to install it.
trans-unit.target: Click the Update button for the package to install it.

trans-unit.source: If your project was created with one of the earlier versions of SCP.NET that did not use NuGet for package updates, you must perform the following steps to update to the new version:
trans-unit.target: If your project was created with one of the earlier versions of SCP.NET that did not use NuGet for package updates, you must perform the following steps to update to the new version:

trans-unit.source: 1. In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: 1. In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: 2. Using the Search field, search for, and then add, Microsoft.SCP.Net.SDK to the project.
trans-unit.target: 2. Using the Search field, search for, and then add, Microsoft.SCP.Net.SDK to the project.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: Test a topology locally
trans-unit.target: Test a topology locally

trans-unit.source: Although it is easy to deploy a topology to a cluster, in some cases, you may need to test a topology locally.
trans-unit.target: Although it is easy to deploy a topology to a cluster, in some cases, you may need to test a topology locally.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to run and test the example topology in this tutorial locally in your development environment.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to run and test the example topology in this tutorial locally in your development environment.

trans-unit.source: Local testing only works for basic, C# only topologies.
trans-unit.target: Local testing only works for basic, C# only topologies.

trans-unit.source: You should not use local testing for hybrid topologies or topologies that use multiple streams, as you will receive errors.
trans-unit.target: You should not use local testing for hybrid topologies or topologies that use multiple streams, as you will receive errors.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the project properties, change the Output type to Console Application.
trans-unit.target: In the project properties, change the Output type to Console Application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>output type</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>output type</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Remember to change the Output type back to Class Library before you deploy the topology to a cluster.
trans-unit.target: Remember to change the Output type back to Class Library before you deploy the topology to a cluster.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, then select Add > New Item.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, then select Add > New Item.

trans-unit.source: Select Class and enter LocalTest.cs as the class name.
trans-unit.target: Select Class and enter LocalTest.cs as the class name.

trans-unit.source: Finally, click Add.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click Add.

trans-unit.source: Open LocalTest.cs and add the following using statement at the top:
trans-unit.target: Open LocalTest.cs and add the following using statement at the top:

trans-unit.source: Use the following as the contents of the LocalTest class:
trans-unit.target: Use the following as the contents of the LocalTest class:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the code comments.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the code comments.

trans-unit.source: This code uses LocalContext to run the components in the development environment, and it persists the data stream between components to text files on the local drive.
trans-unit.target: This code uses LocalContext to run the components in the development environment, and it persists the data stream between components to text files on the local drive.

trans-unit.source: Open Program.cs and add the following to the Main method:
trans-unit.target: Open Program.cs and add the following to the Main method:

trans-unit.source: Save the changes, then click F5 or select Debug > Start Debugging to start the project.
trans-unit.target: Save the changes, then click F5 or select Debug > Start Debugging to start the project.

trans-unit.source: A console window should appear, and log status as the tests progress.
trans-unit.target: A console window should appear, and log status as the tests progress.

trans-unit.source: When Tests finished appears, press any key to close the window.
trans-unit.target: When Tests finished appears, press any key to close the window.

trans-unit.source: Use Windows Explorer to locate the directory that contains your project, for example, **C:\Users\\Documents\Visual Studio 2013\Projects\WordCount\WordCount. In this directory, open **Bin, and then click Debug. You should see the text files that were produced when the tests ran: sentences.txt, counter.txt, and splitter.txt. Open each text file and inspect the data.
trans-unit.target: Use Windows Explorer to locate the directory that contains your project, for example, **C:\Users\\Documents\Visual Studio 2013\Projects\WordCount\WordCount. In this directory, open **Bin, and then click Debug. You should see the text files that were produced when the tests ran: sentences.txt, counter.txt, and splitter.txt. Open each text file and inspect the data.

trans-unit.source: String data is persisted as an array of decimal values in these files.
trans-unit.target: String data is persisted as an array of decimal values in these files.

trans-unit.source: For example, \[[97,103,111]] in the splitter.txt file is the word 'and'.
trans-unit.target: For example, \[[97,103,111]] in the splitter.txt file is the word 'and'.

trans-unit.source: Although testing a basic word count application locally is pretty trivial, the real value comes when you have a complex topology that communicates with external data sources or performs complex data analysis.
trans-unit.target: Although testing a basic word count application locally is pretty trivial, the real value comes when you have a complex topology that communicates with external data sources or performs complex data analysis.

trans-unit.source: When you are working on such a project, you may need to set breakpoints and step through the code in your components to isolate issues.
trans-unit.target: When you are working on such a project, you may need to set breakpoints and step through the code in your components to isolate issues.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to set the Project type back to Class Library before deploying to a Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to set the Project type back to Class Library before deploying to a Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Log information
trans-unit.target: Log information

trans-unit.source: You can easily log information from your topology components by using Context.Logger.
trans-unit.target: You can easily log information from your topology components by using Context.Logger.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following will create an informational log entry:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following will create an informational log entry:

trans-unit.source: Logged information can be viewed from the Hadoop Service Log, which is found in Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Logged information can be viewed from the Hadoop Service Log, which is found in Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Expand the entry for your Storm on HDInsight cluster, then expand Hadoop Service Log.
trans-unit.target: Expand the entry for your Storm on HDInsight cluster, then expand Hadoop Service Log.

trans-unit.source: Finally, select the log file to view.
trans-unit.target: Finally, select the log file to view.

trans-unit.source: The logs are stored in the Azure Storage account that is used by your cluster.
trans-unit.target: The logs are stored in the Azure Storage account that is used by your cluster.

trans-unit.source: If this is a different subscription than the one you are logged in to with Visual Studio, you need to log in to the subscription that contains the storage account to view this information.
trans-unit.target: If this is a different subscription than the one you are logged in to with Visual Studio, you need to log in to the subscription that contains the storage account to view this information.

trans-unit.source: View error information
trans-unit.target: View error information

trans-unit.source: To view errors that have occurred in a running topology, use the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To view errors that have occurred in a running topology, use the following steps:

trans-unit.source: From Server Explorer, right-click the Storm on HDInsight cluster, and select View Storm topologies.
trans-unit.target: From Server Explorer, right-click the Storm on HDInsight cluster, and select View Storm topologies.

trans-unit.source: For the Spout and Bolts, the Last Error column will have information on the last error that has occurred.
trans-unit.target: For the Spout and Bolts, the Last Error column will have information on the last error that has occurred.

trans-unit.source: Select the Spout Id or Bolt Id for the component that has an error listed.
trans-unit.target: Select the Spout Id or Bolt Id for the component that has an error listed.

trans-unit.source: On the details page that is displayed, additional error information will be listed in the Errors section at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: On the details page that is displayed, additional error information will be listed in the Errors section at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: To obtain more information, select a Port from the Executors section of the page to see the Storm worker log for the last few minutes.
trans-unit.target: To obtain more information, select a Port from the Executors section of the page to see the Storm worker log for the last few minutes.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you have learned how to develop and deploy Storm topologies from the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio, learn how to <link><linkText>Process events from Azure Event Hub with Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have learned how to develop and deploy Storm topologies from the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio, learn how to <link><linkText>Process events from Azure Event Hub with Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For an example of a C# topology that splits stream data into multiple streams, see <link><linkText>C# Storm example</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For an example of a C# topology that splits stream data into multiple streams, see <link><linkText>C# Storm example</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To discover more information about creating C# topologies, visit <link><linkText>SCP.NET GettingStarted.md</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To discover more information about creating C# topologies, visit <link><linkText>SCP.NET GettingStarted.md</linkText><title></title></link>.
